para.paratext: Demonstrative evidence includes anything addressed directly to the senses of the court or the jury except the testimony of witnesses and documentary evidence. It includes evidence like photographs, diagrams, computer-generated reenactments, blackboards, charts, placards, models, anatomical charts or drawings,[1] and other things[2] that clarify and illustrate the issues in the case.

Demonstrative evidence may be used during opening statements, closing arguments, direct examination, and cross-examination.[
3]

The Georgia Supreme Court has ruled that demonstrative evidence (as distinguished from evidence used to illustrate a witness's testimony) may be admitted into evidence and sent out with the jury during deliberations because it is not subject to the continuing witness objection.[
4]

An identification process, similar to authentication of writings, is necessary to show that the object offered in evidence is, in fact, what it purports to be. This identification process varies with the nature of the object.

Materials used for illustration may, but need not, be introduced in evidence. The trial court has discretion to determine if demonstrative evidence is admissible, and its decision will not be reversed unless abused.[
5]

Some cases confuse the distinction between “demonstrative” evidence and “real” evidence. “ Real” evidence involves the production in court of some object which had a direct part in the incident in question. “ Demonstrative” evidence involves the production in court of prepared materials that have no probative value in themselves but serve as visual aids for the jury.[
6 ] The foundation is established by showing that the demonstrative evidence clarifies or illustrates issues in the case or other evidence. For example, checks from a bank were permitted as demonstrative evidence to compare with the check the defendant gave a merchant.[
7]

Demonstrative evidence may be shown to the jury if a witness states that this evidence will assist in clarifying the testimony. To be admissible, demonstrative evidence must fairly and accurately depict what it is offered to illustrate and not mislead, confuse, or prejudice the jury.[
8] Foundation witnesses must have personal knowledge of the matter demonstrated but do not have to be the individuals who created the evidence (who took the photograph, drew the diagram, etc.). [9]

If demonstrative evidence deviates from the matter illustrated in some way, a party may ask the court to give an instruction to the jury that clarifies the limited purpose of the exhibit (i.e., the photograph is being admitted to show the configuration of the intersection, not the lighting conditions at the time of the wreck). [10]

Georgia's new Evidence Code made little change to Georgia's law on demonstrative evidence; however, the Georgia Supreme Court has stated that the new Code requires us to look to federal precedent, and not the old Georgia case law to interpret the demonstrative evidence rules.[
11] The Federal Rules of Evidence contain very little material in regard to demonstrative evidence. The identification of demonstrative evidence is included with authentication of writings.[
12] Rule 901(a) provides that the requirement of authentication or identification as a condition precedent to admissibility is satisfied by evidence sufficient to support a finding that the matter in question is what its proponent claims.
O.C.G.A. § 24-9-901(a) is identical. Thus, practitioners should review federal case law when briefing the issues for the court.
Ruffin v. State, 333 Ga. App. 793, 777 S.E.2d 262 (2015).

O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71.1 provides that exhibits tendered to the court as evidence in a criminal or civil trial shall not be open to public inspection without approval of the assigned judge. Photographs of the exhibit may be allowed.
Tench v. Galaxy Appliance & Furniture Sales, Inc., 255 Ga. App. 829, 567 S.E.2d 53 (2002).

Moss v. State, 274 Ga. 740, 559 S.E.2d 433 (2002), held “demonstrative evidence is to be received into evidence and go out with the jury during deliberations.”
In other words, the continuing witness objection which prevents some items from going out with the jury does not apply to demonstrative evidence.
C.J.S., Evidence § 601 .
Allen v. State, 347 Ga. App. 731, 820 S.E.2d 747 (2018).

Cornell v. State, 265 Ga. 904, 905, 463 S.E.2d 702 (1995). See Rickman v. State, 304 Ga. 61, 816 S.E.2d 4 (2018), for an analysis regarding demonstrative evidence in a criminal case under the new Evidence Code. In that case, the Georgia Supreme Court held photographs of a reenactment where the location was the same as where the crime occurred, the cars used were the same as those involved during the actual altercation, and the policemen depicting the parties involved matched the height of the actual parties, were admissible as demonstrative evidence.
Department of Transp. v. Mendel, 237 Ga. App. 900, 905, 517 S.E.2d 365 (1999).
Weinstein's Evidence, ¶¶ 901(a)(01), (02).
